I would be happy to help with that. The Pittsburgh sleep quality index is a tool for evaluating the quality and quantity of sleep. It consists of 10 items scored on a 0-3 scale, yielding a total score out of 30. Higher scores reflect poorer sleep quality. Possible adverse effects of sleep quality are fatigue and daytime sleepiness. I suggest including both a screening measure (e.g., yes/no question on the informed consent form) and an outcome measure as a formal post-treatment assessment. The self-rating depression scale is a widely-used measure of depressive symptomatology. It is a 20-item scale with items scored on a 0-3 scale, yielding a range from 0-60. Possible adverse effects of depression are sadness and hopelessness. I suggest including an outcome measure as a formal post-treatment assessment. The Montreal Cognitive Assessment is a brief screening instrument used to measure cognitive, neurosensory, and neuro-motor status. It has been shown to detect significant cognitive dysfunction in a clinical setting with a high degree of reliability and validity. Possible adverse effects of cognitive impairment are memory loss and slowed reaction time. I suggest including an outcome measure as a formal post-treatment assessment. That's helpful. Are there any other measures you would recommend considering for inclusion in the protocol?

Great. For the self-rating depression scale, I recommend using the Center for Epidemiological Studies Depression Scale for the Elderly (CES-D). Do you have a preference regarding the time frame for these assessments?

And finally, the Montreal Cognitive Assessment will assess cognitive function in patients using a short screening tool. This measure will be used to identify any cognitive impairment in patients following surgery. It would be useful to assess this outcome measure both preoperatively and postoperatively. Since it is a shorter assessment tool compared to other measures, it would be useful to assess at multiple time points in case any changes occur.

Blood chemistry: Parameters to be measured will be alanine aminotransferase (ALT), aspartate aminotransferase (AST), bilirubin, blood urea nitrogen (BUN), creatinine, and creatinine clearance. model_response: The secondary outcome measures include the following: Secondary Measure Detailed Information Primary Measure Mental well-being The primary outcome measures are the change of HADS anxiety and depression subscales. These measures are self-reported and self-assessed at each of the assessment time points. Mild symptoms of depression and/or anxiety are quite common among individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS). It is expected that the intervention will lead to reductions in anxiety and depression. Depression is a known correlate of poor quality of life in people with MS. Anxiety, although not as well studied, may also be a correlate of poor quality of life in MS. The study is aimed at reducing symptom levels of anxiety and depression, therefore these outcomes are the focus of the main analyses.  Psychological distress The Self-Report Questionnaire 20+ (SRQ 20+) The primary outcome measure will be self-reported mental well-being at 12 weeks and at 24 weeks. The SRQ 20+ is a measure of self-reported psychological distress. It is a shortened version of the original Social Readout Questionnaire, with 20 items rated on a 4-point scale. It is a measure of general emotional distress, with good psychometric properties and is widely used for research and clinical purposes.  Worry The primary outcome measure will be self-reported worry. Worry will be assessed via the Worry Questionnaire (Worry-B), a 4-item measure of anxiety. This is a widely used measure in clinical and research settings. Individuals rate their past 7-day level of worry on a scale from 0 to 4. The scale provides a total anxiety score for each assessment. It has good psychometric properties.  Physical Measures Physical health The primary outcome measure for physical health is the self-report Primary Outcome Measure (POM), which is derived from a series of self-report questions relating to MS disease characteristics, medication and comorbidities. The POM is based on questions from the Patient-Reported Outcome Measurement Information System (PROMIS®) developed by NIH. The PROMIS items on which the Primary Outcome Measure (POM) is based

The MFIS is a measure of the fatigue experienced by individuals with MS. The PSQI is a measure of self-reported sleep quality. The PES assesses the degree to which pain has interfered with daily activities. The GSES is a measure of self-efficacy with respect to performing activities and tasks. The UWSES-MS is a measure of MS-specific self-efficacy beliefs. The BFIMS is a measure of individuals' ability to find benefit in the stressful experiences related to MS. The SWLS is a measure of individuals' perception of their own well-being. The RYFFPWB is a measure of the positive valence, in addition to the negative valence, in people's lives.
The secondary outcome measures will be assessed at baseline, as well as at weeks 4, 8, and 24.

model_response: The other measure I suggest is the Functional Oral Intake Measure (FOIM). It's a quantitative measure of oral intake capacity, which includes items such as swallowing, mastication, and bolus control. It involves a standardized script and is completed by a trained observer as the patient is eating. The FOIM also has good responsiveness in evaluating change in swallowing function.

The FOIS can be assessed pre- and post-intervention, with a decrease in score indicating improvement in swallowing function. It's a reliable and sensitive measure of swallowing function, and can be used to confirm the changes observed with videofluoroscopy.

Another important measure to include is the Modified Dysphagia Severity Scale (MDSS). It is the most widely used measure to assess dysphagia in clinical practice. It evaluates five parameters: solids, liquids, weight-bearing liquids, consistencies, solids texture-thick and lumpy. It provides a numerical assessment of dysphagia along with a visual analog scale for severity.  Another measure that could be useful is the Eating Assessment Tool (eat). It is a quick screening tool used to classify patients according to the degree of eating difficulty and is easy to use in research and practice. The highest score indicates no difficulty eating. I would suggest including the MDSS and eat in the final analysis. Is there anything else I can assist you with regarding your outcome measures?
The PAS will be evaluated at baseline and at the end of the treatment period, which is 6 weeks. This will allow you to assess changes in aspiration risk following treatment.

A speech intelligibility assessment would be important to include in your study. It will help evaluate the effectiveness of the intervention in improving speech intelligibility for individuals with dysphagia. Additionally, a swallowing questionnaire, such as the MDSSQ, would be useful for assessing the participants' quality of life before and after the intervention.

The FDS will be assessed at baseline and throughout the treatment period, which is 3 weeks. This will allow you to monitor changes in swallowing function over time, and assess the effectiveness of the intervention.

Yes, we should also include the Eating-Behavior Scale for Dysphagia (EBSD), which is a self-report measure that evaluates swallowing-associated anxiety and other psychosocial factors. This measure will provide valuable information about the treatment effects on any associated emotional or psychological issues related to dysphagia.

The DOSS will be evaluated from baseline to the end of treatment, which is a period of 3 weeks. This will allow you to assess changes in dysphagia severity over time and determine the effectiveness of the intervention.

Secondary outcome measures are measures that are related to the primary outcome measures, but not as directly influenced by the intervention. These measures are often used to evaluate the effect of the intervention on other aspects of the dysphagia and to help understand the mechanisms of the treatment effect.

The DHI is scored by adding the scores of the 25 items together. The resulting total score is then converted to a number between 0 and 100, where a higher score indicates a greater impact of dysphagia on quality of life.
The DHI can be assessed at baseline and again at 3 months after treatment to evaluate changes in quality of life. Is there anything else I should know about the DHI?

NT-proBNP is a biomarker of left ventricular dysfunction. In this particular case, a decrease in NT-proBNP level reflects improvement of left ventricular dysfunction, and the effectiveness of treatment. It should be measured at baseline and at 6 months.
Measures of change in NTproBNP, an acute and sensitive biomarker of heart failure severity and response to therapy.
An appropriate time frame for this measure would be "at study completion (T0 to T6)".

KCQL is a novel natriuretic peptide that is an independent predictor of adverse cardiac events in patients undergoing heart transplantation and is considered a biomarker indicative of underlying heart failure risk. KCQL is typically measured as a continuous variable as follows: 0-50: 0-2 points; KCQL > 50-100: 3 points; and >1000: 5 points. Therefore, a reduction in KCQL would reflect an improvement in ventricular function and is an indicator of better prognosis.
It can be described as "a 5-point change in the Kansas City Cardiomyopathy Questionnaire score compared to baseline."
An appropriate time frame for this measure would be "6 months." 5.

The 6-minute walk test is a simple, safe and well-validated test to assess functional exercise capacity in patients with heart failure and valvular disease. A  better 6-minute walk test reflects better functional exercise capacity, and a greater improvement in 6-minute walk test shows improvement in disease severity and treatment response.
You can describe it as "25 meter change in 6 minute walk test compared to baseline."
An appropriate time frame for this measure would be "6 months."

model_response: Patient satisfaction can be measured by using an instrument such as the Patient Satisfaction Questionnaire. This tool includes 14 items rated on a five-point Likert scale. The questions assess the patient's satisfaction with various aspects such as nursing care, meals, and activities. Caregiver satisfaction can be assessed with the Informal Caregiver Satisfaction Item List. This instrument includes 11 items rated on a five-point Likert scale and measures caregiver perceptions of their role and needs. Does this sound reasonable to you?

For patient outcomes, we can use the Clinical Dementia Rating Scale (CDR) and the Alzheimer's disease Cooperative Study - Activities of Daily Living Inventory (ADCS-ADL) to measure changes in functional status. The Short Informant Questionnaire on Cognitive Decline in the Elderly (SICDE) will assess changes in cognitive function, and caregiver burden will be assessed using the Burden Interview.

Assessing patient outcomes is critical to determine the effect the intervention had on the patient's health. The ability to perform activities of daily living (ADLs), such as bathing, dressing, and walking, is important in determining patient outcomes following discharge from skilled care. There are many tools that can be used to assess ADLs and they are often used to assess the patient's preparedness before discharge from skilled care. One of the most widely used is the Katz Index of Independence in ADLs. This is a simple tool that evaluates a patient's ability to perform eight ADLs on a scale of 1 (no help required) to 4 (patient requires assistance). Another useful tool is the MDS Level of Functioning assessment, which is used to assess a patient's level of cognitive or physical impairment and can estimate their ability to recover. To assess quality of life following the intervention, we can use a tool called the Nottingham Quality of Life Profile, which assesses five domains: physical, social, emotional, cognitive, and spiritual. This questionnaire rates each domain on a one to five scale. When used in conjunction with other measures of patient functioning, such as the Katz Index, it is a useful tool to evaluate the benefits of the intervention. Measuring caregiver outcomes is an important component of the study as it will help determine the impact the intervention had on the caregiver's life as well as to provide information to develop future interventions. Caregiver burden is a critical factor in assessing the outcomes associated with providing care for someone with dementia and can be assessed with a tool like the Burden Interview. Burden is measured in the context of the resources expended to provide care, the impact on the caregiver's daily life, and the level of satisfaction with the caregiving experience. Caregiver distress can be measured with the Geriatric Depression scale, an 11-item instrument used to detect depression in the elderly population. Caregiver sense of competence can be assessed with the Burden Interview or the Caregiver Competencies Survey. Caregivers' perception of the value of the intervention to their lives can be measured with the Satisfaction With Care Instrument. How should we best proceed? Is

To assess the caregiver's experience and level of training with providing care at home, I would recommend using the Caring for the Patient at Home (CaPH) self-efficacy measure. This scale includes 26 items on a 5-point scale, with higher scores indicating greater self-confidence and ability to care for the patient at home. One of the CaPH subscales, the Personal Care subscale, assesses the caregiver's comfort with performing activities of daily living, bathing, dressing, and grooming. The Home Maintenance subscale assesses the caregiver's confidence in maintaining a safe and clean home environment. The Emotional Support subscale measures the caregiver's ability to provide emotional support and companionship to the patient. Another key area for caregiver self-assessment is the level of support and assistance they have received from friends, family, and community agencies. The Needs and Resources for Emotional Support subscale addresses these issues. Does that sound like a good set of measures to assess the patient and caregiver?

For the patient's function and quality of life, we can use the Telecare Rehabilitation Measurement Scale (TRMS). It has 20 items and 5 subscales that measure the patient's self-reported physical health and functioning. Higher scores on the TRMS indicate greater function and quality of life. Would you like more information about these measures?

To assess caregiver burden, we can use the Burden Assessment Scales Short Form (BAS-SF). It consists of 10 items on a 4-point Likert scale, and lower scores indicate less burden. The measure takes into account the burden associated with the patient's physical and cognitive status. It can also assess the caregiver's perception of the patient's quality of life, and can be given to both the caregiver and the patient. We can also use the Center for Epidemiological Studies-Depression Scale (CES-D), which measures depression in caregivers. This can be a useful tool to evaluate the burden and depressive symptoms of caregivers. Another tool that can be useful to evaluate caregiver burden and distress is the Short Caregiver Burden Scale (SCBS). It consists of 20 Likert-type items and was designed to assess burden specifically in informal caregivers of persons with dementia. We must also consider financial burden. Are there any tools available to evaluate this burden? In terms of financial burden, we often use tools such as the Client Financial Burden Assessment Questionnaire (CFBAQ). It includes 10 items that assess factors including out-of-pocket expenses, employment status, and household income. What else can we assess in terms of outcomes? Do you have any other key measures in mind?

The MFI is scored using a 4-point Likert scale (0-no fatigue, 1-mild fatigue, 2-moderate fatigue, and 3-severe fatigue), and a total MFI score is derived. Improvement of Quality of Life is assessed by the Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy-Hemato-Oncology (FACT-HOsubramblevel). The FACT-HOsubramblevel measures patients' physical functioning, role functioning, emotional well-being, and social functioning using a 7-point Likert scale (1-worst, 7-best). Improvement of Mood is assessed with the Profile of Mood states (POMS). The POMS is a validated self-report questionnaire that encompasses 5 mood states: depression, anxiety, anger, somatic distress, and tiredness. Participants' mood states are rated for the past 24 hours and each is scored using a 5-point Likert scale (1-low, 5-high).

The Improvement of Quality of Life measure will also be evaluated using the Functional Assessment of Chronic Illness Therapy-General (FACT-G) subscales. The higher the score, the better the quality of life. The score range for FACT-G is 0-444, with lower scores indicating higher quality of life. The time frame for this measure is from baseline (pre-randomization) to the 5-month follow-up.

Lastly, the Improvement of Mood measure assesses the intervention's impact on participants' mood state. It will be measured using the European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer Quality of Life Questionnaire core module (EORTC QLQ-C30), with a score range of 0-100, higher scores indicating better mood. This measure will also be assessed from baseline to 5-month follow-up.

The next secondary outcome measure is mechanical ventilation requirement. It provides insights into the impact of early cessation of sedation on mechanical ventilation requirements.

The next secondary outcome measure is the incidence of delirium or sedation burden. This measure assesses the occurrence of cognitive deterioration due to sedation and helps evaluate the impact of early cessation of sedation and TTM on the mental status of ICU patients.

We also have the incidence of delirium as a secondary outcome measure. This measure evaluates the occurrence of delirium in patients with a favourable EEG after early cessation of sedation and TTM. It helps identify the impact of early weaning from sedation on delirium in ICU patients.

The next secondary outcome measure is the incidence of delirium as a composite end-point. This measure assesses the development of delirium in the ICU within 3 days of ICU admission. Monitoring the incidence of delirium helps ensure patient safety and provides valuable insights into the neurocognitive impact of early cessation of sedation and TTM.

We'll track the number of infections (including Clostridium difficile infections and ventilator-associated pneumonia) as a secondary outcome measure. Monitoring the occurrence of these infections can provide insights into the safety and efficacy of early cessation of sedation and TTM in preventing nosocomial infections.

We'll also track cost-effectiveness as a secondary outcome measure. The cost of the intervention will be compared to the cost of the current standard of care over 30 days in the ICU. Monitoring cost-effectiveness helps evaluate the affordability of the intervention.

model_response: Sure, the secondary outcome measure is the maximum serum concentration of NNC0194-0499 in the body after the first dose (Visit 2, Day 1), measured in nanograms per milliliter (ng/mL). This value helps us gauge the overall accumulation of NNC0194-0499 in the body and its absorption rate.

Correct! The next secondary outcome measure is the AUC0180-0499SD, which stands for the total area under the curve, from 0 to infinity, for NNC0194-0499. It is measured in nanomoles per liter per hour (nmol/L/hour) and provides information on the total amount of drug in your body over time. This measure also starts from Visit 2, Day 1, pre- dose and ends at the end of the study (Visit 9, Day 36).

The other key secondary outcome measure is the tmax,0499,SD, or time of maximal observed concentration. It represents the time at which the concentration of NNC0194-0499 is highest in your serum after a single dose. The time frame is the same as the primary outcome measure, that is, from baseline (Visit 2, Day 1) to the final end- of study visit (Visit 9, Day 36). These two measures, along with other parameters like area under the concentration-time curve, help us understand drug absorption and elimination from your body.

That's right. The third secondary outcome measure is tfinal,0499,SD, which stands for the terminal elimination half-life of NNC0194-0499 in your body. This measure indicates how long it takes for the amount of drug in your serum to decrease by half after the drug has reached its maximum concentration. The time frame for this measure is the same as the previous outcome measures. The fourth secondary measure is the AUC0-499,SD, which stands for the total area under the serum concentration-time curve between 0 and 499 hours after dosing. This measure represents the total quantity of NNC0194-0499 in your body over a 48-hour period, from hours 0 to 499. The time frame for this measure is also the same as the previous measures.

The next outcome measure is hVss,0499, SD, which stands for the half-life of NNC0194-0499 in your serum. The half-life is the time taken for the concentration of the drug in your serum to decrease to half of its initial value. The time frame for measuring this outcome is the same as the other outcome measures.

That's correct! In addition, they provide information on the drug's clearance, which can be important for dosing and monitoring patients' response to therapy.

model_response: Great thought. We can measure the following secondary outcome measures: 1) Time to progression, which is measured from the first administration of IV vitamin C. 2) Response rate, measured as a combination of objective response and patient assessed response. Objective response can be assessed using Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST) and patient assessment can be done using the 11-point Cantrell response scale. 3) Survival time, which is measured from the day of randomization. 4) Toxicity management, which will be assessed by determining the maximum tolerated dose of vitamin C. 5) Biomarker analysis: We can analyze for changes in pre-specified biomarkers in blood at specific time intervals. These markers may include, but are not limited to, LDH, C3, C4, and albumin levels. 6) Incidence of adverse effects, which will be recorded using the Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (CTCAE) criteria.

Any thoughts? One other measure that could be considered is the 6-minute walk test (6MWT). This test assesses physical exercise capacity and can be used to monitor treatment response and toxicity on patients with cancer. 6MWT has good feasibility, safety, and reproducibility among different raters and across various populations. The distance that patients can successfully walk in 6 minutes is measured.

One other secondary outcome measure worthwhile monitoring is the change in adherence to the 6-minute walk test (6MWT). The 6MWT is a measure of exercise tolerance and overall functional status. We can assess this via a 6-minute walk test before treatment, after the first cycle of chemotherapy, and at the end of treatment. This way, we can assess changes in exercise tolerance over time and compare the two groups.

Another important measure to consider is the quality of life. We can assess this using the EuroQol 5-dimensional questionnaire, which assesses 5 dimensions of quality of life: mobility, self-care, usual activities, pain/discomfort, and anxiety/depression. We can assess this measure at baseline, during each chemotherapy cycle (1-4), at 6 months, and at 12 months.

One other important measure to consider is the change in physical fitness over time. We can measure this using commonly available tests such as the 6-minute walk test and the functional impairment assessment test. The 6-minute walk test is a test of aerobic endurance used to measure the change in 6-minute walking distance over time. The functional impairment assessment test is a timed test to measure the ability to perform physical tasks such as walking, climbing stairs, and lifting objects. We can assess the change in these measures at baseline, 1, 4, and 12 months.

The phase has been marked as "not applicable" because the study is not a randomized controlled trial. The phase of a clinical trial is the level of the clinical development of the drug, device, or intervention. The phases are: Phase I (discovery and pre-clinical testing), Phase II (pre-clinical testing in humans to assess pharmacology), Phase III (randomized controlled trials in a large number of people with the disease or condition), and Phase IV (post-approval study of the drug or intervention in large numbers of people, often in different settings, to confirm its long-term safety and benefits). The phases are generally needed before a new drug, device, or intervention can be approved for general use.

Of course. E' can be used to assess changes in regional systolic function in the settings of acute cardiac stress. Specifically, it can be used to determine systolic regional performance after volume expanding hemodynamic stressors such as infiltration with a contrast medium in echocardiography. This can also be used after administration of vasodilators such as dibutyl ether or adenosine. It can be calculated as the ratio of early to late septal A' to S' velocity changes. To accurately compute this measure, a frame of acquisition must be set that includes the 3 early diastolic e' and S waves for this calculation. A sample report will be as follows: E' = S' - early diastolic S' (during rapid filling). E' can be expressed as an absolute value or an indexed value (normalized to some percentage of stroke volume or end-diastolic volume). However, it must be noted that E' is not suitable as an index of global LV function because the E' pattern may be normal in disease states associated with global LV systolic dysfunction. Would you have any additional suggestions for measures to evaluate fluid responsiveness?
That would be an E' variation at 75% of the time of vascular occlusion (T0+0.75Tfin). This measure will be assessed at the end of 5 minutes after the end of vascular filling.
∆E'late will be measured using tissue Doppler. For your convenience, I have also included a template of the tissue Doppler setup that you can easily transfer to your institution's program.

model_response: Good idea. To evaluate changes in activities of daily living (ADL) and instrumental activities of daily living (IADL), I suggest using the Barthel Index. It comprises 10 items related to physical and functional abilities necessary for independent living. You will be able to observe the improvement in ADL and IADL after the intervention. For measures of physical functioning, what do you think would be appropriate?

The Barthel Index evaluates the level of independence in performing basic ADL, asking questions such as "Can the subject roll in bed without assistance?" and "Can the subject tie his/her shoelaces?" The ICOPE questionnaire is a 30-item measure that includes several general questions on the participant's ability to perform various tasks unassisted or requiring minimal assistance, such as "Is the person able to go to a neighborhood shop by themself," "Can the person cook a meal for themself," and "Can the person make cups of tea?" The Lawton Scale measures the participant's ability to perform various instrumental activities of daily living, such as preparing meals and managing personal finances, on a 7-point scale from "needing no assistance" to "needing assistance or help." This measure will help us understand the impact of the exercises on the participant's ability to complete essential tasks of daily living.

I recommend using the Timed-Up and Go (timed get up and go) test, the 10-meter walk test, and the one-leg standing balance test. These measures will assess mobility and fall risk. The Timed-Up and Go test assesses mobility and balance in a 30-second period. The 10-meter walk test assesses gait and balance over a distance. The one-leg standing balance test assesses static balance. The time frame for these measures will be at baseline and at 6- and 12-month follow-up visits.

For the balance test, the Timed Up and Go test is a commonly used measure of static-dynamic balance in elderly individuals. It involves performing a timed chair-to-standing task, with the participants being instructed to keep as upright as possible for 10 seconds, as well as standing up from a seated position without using arms for support. The test is performed in standing and in three different positions: normal stance, forward, and tandem. This test has been shown to be a sensitive and specific measure of static and dynamic balance in elderly persons. It needs to be administered in three different positions because the lateral static balance tends to be better in front than in the other positions and dynamic balance is better in the back position, so it's important to test in all conditions. We usually perform the test at 0, 6, and 12 months. Does this time frame sound appropriate?

For self-perceived health, the Nottingham Health Profile questionnaire is a suitable measure. It provides information on the overall health status and changes over time. To assess adverse health outcomes, we can use the incidence of falls, hospitalization, and morbidity. These measures will help us determine the effectiveness of our intervention. Do these measures align with your understanding of the study's goals?

These measures will be obtained at baseline and after the study completion. The time frame for these measures will be 6 months or an average of 1 year. This duration allows for adequate study and follow-up without compromising on treatment efficacy. Are there any other measures we can include in our protocol?

The two interventions being compared are Mirabegron versus placebo. 
Because the trialists are using a parallel assignment model, they don't need to list the treatment allocation concealment measures. The three factors are: 1) participants will be masked - neither the participant nor the investigator will know which treatment is being given (they use the term "triple masking" when it is applied to both participant and investigator); 2) blinding of the treatment allocation concealment process, which means that the person(s) responsible for product allocation will be masked; 3) blinding of the investigator, so the investigator does not know which treatment group the participant is in.
A crossover trial is an observational study where one of the phases is an interventional trial, i.e, an RCT. If the crossover phase is used as the main analysis when the treatment effects are the same for both treatments, this type of study is considered a type of equivalence trial. Not all RCTs are crossover trials. The term may only be used when there is a realistic possibility that the treatments being studied have similar effects, i.e, their intended uses are the same.
A RCT nested within a trial is any randomized controlled trial where a subset of the study population is randomly assigned to an active treatment arm within the larger study design. For example, an open-label RCT for the treatment of a particular medical condition is nested within a larger open-label trial to evaluate the same treatment for other conditions. As with all RCTs, allocation concealment must be considered. However, in contrast to stand-alone RCTs, the sample size is usually smaller.  In this example, one would only need to randomize a significant subset of those in the larger study to the active treatment rather than all of them.

The exercise arm would prescribe a 3-month program of exercise, walking, strength-training, and stretching, and the control arm would be usual care.

Excellent choice! The following additional measures would complete the toolbox: Timed Up and Go Test (TUG), Iowa Warm Hands Test (IWHT), and Single Leg Stand Test (SLS). Please select your choices.
Timed-Up and Go Test (TUG): The Timed Up and Go Test (TUG) is a clinical test of static and dynamic balance. It's commonly used to determine if an individual is at high risk for falling or in patients with rehabilitation from an illness or injury. The test consists of a timed get up and go from a seated position.
International Classification for ehFatigue Scale Inventory (FES-I): The purpose of the FES-I is to diagnose the presence and severity of fatigue in individuals. The scale has 12 items which are rated on a 5-point Likert scale. The result is summed and transformed to a 0-100 scale.
Beck Depression Inventory (BDI): The Beck Depression Inventory (BDI) is a self-report inventory which measures depression. It has 21 items, which are rated to evaluate the severity of symptoms of depression. The BDI can be used for screening, diagnosis, and to monitor treatment response.
Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI): The PSQI is a self-report instrument that is designed to measure subjective sleep quality. It includes 19 items rated on a Likert scale on a 0-4 scale. The PSQI total score is the sum of the participants' scores on all the items, and it ranges from 0 to 24, with higher scores indicating worse sleep quality.
The Iowa Warm Hands Test (IWHT): The Iowa Warm Hand Test (IWHT) is a clinical test of static and dynamic hand strength and weakness. It is a test of hand strength where each extremity is separately tested on a dynamometer to measure hand grip strength.
Single Leg Stand Test (SLS): The Single Leg Stand (SLS) test evaluates static balance and it assesses the ability to maintain a one-footed stance (i.e., standing on one leg). The clinician will evaluate the patients' ability to balance in this situation.

model_response: Great question. The second primary outcome measure could be the "Change From Baseline in the Investigator's Global Impression of Severity of Disease (IGiSD) score at the End of Treatment (Part 1)". This measure will assess the disease progression during treatment. Do you have any other considerations for the primary outcome measures?

The measure description for this outcome measure could be "Objective tumor measurements (i.e., RECIST 1.1)." The time frame for this measure would be "Baseline, then every 8 weeks for the next 16 weeks until disease progression or discontinuation from study." This will allow us to monitor treatment response over time in patients with ccRCC.
The secondary outcome measures would include disease control, tumor progression-free survival (TPFS), and safety assessments based on the clinical course of all participants. What do you think?

Happy to! The measure descriptions and time frames for the secondary outcome measures following are: 1) "PFS", assessed by RECIST v.1.1, is the time from the date of administration of the first dose of NKTR-214 to event of PFS. Event of PFS will be assessed by the investigator as either a date of confirmed progression or death from any cause. 2) "DOR" will be assessed by RECIST v.1.1 from the date of administration of the first dose of NKTR-214 to the date of confirmed disease progression or death from any cause. 3) "TTR" will be measured from the date of administration of the first dose of NKTR 214 until the time of confirmed disease progression or death. 4) "OS" will be measured from the date of administration of the first dose of NKR-214 until death from any cause. 5) "CBR", assessed by RECIST v.1.1, is defined as the percentage of participants with 0 or 1 tumor lesions. For a partial response, all evaluated lesions must have decreased in size. For a complete response, there must be no measurable or a decrease to 1 evaluable lesion. 6) "Number of Participants with Adverse Events" (AEs) will be captured throughout the study. AEs will be tabulated and tabulated by percentages in the study population. 7) "Pharmacokinetics" must be done per the protocol specified procedures.
These measures will allow us to better understand the treatment's effects on efficacy and safety compared to placebo/standard of care.

Time to response would measure the time taken for 50% of patients to experience CR or CRi based on ELN 2022 criteria. The time frame for this measure would be 3 months.

The duration of the relapse-free period is another important measure of treatment efficacy. It assesses the duration of time before disease progression or relapse occurs after treatment initiation. The time frame for this measure would also be 3 months.

Event-free survival measure evaluates the survival of patients free of disease progression or death. It enables the assessment of disease progression and survival. This measure will be evaluated over a time frame of 3 months.

Overall survival simply reflects the time from randomization to death due to any cause. This measure provides a fundamental understanding of survival impact of DASATINIB monotherapy relative to that of best supportive care. The time frame for overall survival would also be 3 months. These measures would be captured at the end of the third month following start of randomization.

The occurrence of adverse events measure evaluates the rate of treatment-related adverse events. This measure is important for understanding the safety profile of DASATINIB monotherapy and for monitoring patient safety throughout the trial. The time frame for this measure will be 3 months.
